articles.headline: Fisticuffs Over the Route to a Clean-Energy Future
articles.snippet: A Stanford professor’s vision of an economy wholly powered by renewable fuels has drawn a heated rebuttal from scholars who question many of its assumptions.
articles.abstract: A Stanford professor’s vision of an economy wholly powered by renewable fuels has drawn a heated rebuttal from scholars who question many of its assumptions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Could the entire American economy run on renewable energy alone?

articles.headline: China Will Be Part of a Popular Stock Index, Opening the Door to Foreign Money
articles.snippet: Inclusion in MSCI’s emerging markets index, even on a modest scale, will make it more important for foreign money managers to invest in China.
articles.abstract: Inclusion in MSCI’s emerging markets index, even on a modest scale, will make it more important for foreign money managers to invest in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s effort to open its door to foreign investors has received a big push, as its stocks were accepted into a closely followed global index.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Despite Concerns About Blackmail, Flynn Heard C.I.A. Secrets
articles.snippet: If Mike Pompeo, the C.I.A. director, knew of his agency’s concerns about Michael T. Flynn, the national security adviser at the time, he did not share them with the president.
articles.abstract: If Mike Pompeo, the C.I.A. director, knew of his agency’s concerns about Michael T. Flynn, the national security adviser at the time, he did not share them with the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior officials across the government became convinced in January that the incoming national security adviser, Michael T. Flynn, had become vulnerable to Russian blackmail.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Matthew Rosenberg and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Too Hot to Fly? Climate Change May Take a Toll on Air Travel
articles.snippet: Excess heat in Phoenix grounded more than 40 flights in recent days, and scientists say a warming climate could also mean more turbulent rides.
articles.abstract: Excess heat in Phoenix grounded more than 40 flights in recent days, and scientists say a warming climate could also mean more turbulent rides.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent days, American Airlines has been forced to cancel more than 40 flights in Phoenix. The reason: With daytime highs hovering around 120 degrees, it was simply too hot for some smaller jets to take off. Hotter air is thinner air, which makes it more difficult — and sometimes impossible — for planes to generate enough lift.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Rift Over Medicaid and Opioids Imperils Senate Health Bill
articles.snippet: Deep divisions have developed among Senate Republicans over the rate of future spending on Medicaid and how to help opioid addicts who lose drug treatment funds.
articles.abstract: Deep divisions have developed among Senate Republicans over the rate of future spending on Medicaid and how to help opioid addicts who lose drug treatment funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A growing rift among Senate Republicans over federal spending on Medicaid and the opioid epidemic is imperiling legislation to repeal the Affordable Care Act that Senate leaders are trying to put to a vote by the end of next week.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: China Falls Short on Curbing North Korea, Trump Says
articles.snippet: The president’s statement was an extraordinary admission of failure of his strategy for dealing with the North, leaving him with unpalatable options.
articles.abstract: The president’s statement was an extraordinary admission of failure of his strategy for dealing with the North, leaving him with unpalatable options.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Tuesday that China had not succeeded in getting North Korea to curb its nuclear and ballistic missile programs, an extraordinary admission of failure in his strategy for dealing with the rogue regime of Kim Jong-un.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Gardiner Harris

articles.headline: Karen Handel Wins Georgia Special Election, Fending Off Upstart Democrat
articles.snippet: In a demoralizing result for Democrats, Ms. Handel defeated Jon Ossoff, a political newcomer who had drawn an outpouring of support from liberals around the country.
articles.abstract: In a demoralizing result for Democrats, Ms. Handel defeated Jon Ossoff, a political newcomer who had drawn an outpouring of support from liberals around the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Karen Handel, a veteran Republican officeholder, overcame a deluge of liberal money to win a special House election in Georgia on Tuesday, bridging the divide in her party between admirers of President Trump and those made uneasy by his turbulent new administration.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: Democrats Seethe After Georgia Loss: ‘Our Brand Is Worse Than Trump’
articles.snippet: A demoralizing special-election defeat has left some Democrats questioning the leadership and political strategy of Nancy Pelosi, the House minority leader.
articles.abstract: A demoralizing special-election defeat has left some Democrats questioning the leadership and political strategy of Nancy Pelosi, the House minority leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: Democrats scrambled to regroup on Wednesday after a disappointing special election defeat in Georgia, with lawmakers, activists and labor leaders speaking out in public and private to demand a more forceful economic message heading into the 2018 elections.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
